That makes translation easier. Next, the bitmask loop. The loop in Java is for (bit = 0; bit < (1 << D); bit++). So in Fortran, we can loop bit from 0 to 2**D - 1. But 2**D can be calculated as ishft(1, D), which is 1 shifted left by D bits. But in Fortran, the exponentiation operator is **. So 2**D is the same as 1 << D in Java. Another point: in Fortran, when you compute 2**D, if D is 10, then 2**10 is 1024, which is okay. But the loop is from 0 to 2**D -1, which for D=10 is 1023. So the code should be okay. Now, putting it all together. So the Fortran code would look like:

program atcoder_ABC104_C
    implicit none
    integer, parameter :: INF = 100000
    integer :: D, min_val, solve_num, bit, i, j
    integer(kind=8) :: G, score
    integer, allocatable :: p(:), c(:)

    read *, D, G
    allocate(p(0:D-1), c(0:D-1)) do i = 0, D-1
        read *, p(i), c(i)
    end do

    min_val = INF do bit = 0, 2**D - 1
        score = 0
        solve_num = 0

        ! Process all selected problems
        do i = 0, D-1
            if (btest(bit, i)) then
                score = score + 100 * (i + 1) * p(i) + c(i) solve_num = solve_num + p(i)
            end if
        end do

        if (score < G) then
            outer: do i = D-1, 0, -1
                if (.not. btest(bit, i)) then
                    do j = 1, p(i) - 1
                        score = score + 100 * (i + 1)
                        solve_num = solve_num + 1
                        if (score >= G) then
                            exit outer
                        end if
                    end do
                end if
            end do outer
        end if

        if (score >= G .and. solve_num < min_val) then
            min_val = solve_num
        end if
    end do

    print *, min_val

    deallocate(p, c)
end program atcoder_ABC104_C

Now, putting it all together.

So the Fortran code would look like:

program atcoder_ABC104_C
    implicit none
    integer, parameter :: INF = 100000
    integer :: D, min_val, solve_num, bit, i, j
    integer(kind=8) :: G, score
    integer, allocatable :: p(:), c(:)

    read *, D, G
    allocate(p(0:D-1), c(0:D-1))
    do i = 0, D-1
        read *, p(i), c(i)
    end do

    min_val = INF

    do bit = 0, 2**D - 1
        score = 0
        solve_num = 0

        ! Process all selected problems
        do i = 0, D-1
            if (btest(bit, i)) then
                score = score + 100 * (i + 1) * p(i) + c(i)
                solve_num = solve_num + p(i)
            end if
        end do

        if (score < G) then
            outer: do i = D-1, 0, -1
                if (.not. btest(bit, i)) then
                    do j = 1, p(i) - 1
                        score = score + 100 * (i + 1)
                        solve_num = solve_num + 1
                        if (score >= G) then
                            exit outer
                        end if
                    end do
                end if
            end do outer
        end if

        if (score >= G .and. solve_num < min_val) then
            min_val = solve_num
        end if
    end do

    print *, min_val

    deallocate(p, c)
end program atcoder_ABC104_C

Wait, but in the code, when processing the partial problems (the j loop), in the Java code, it's j < p[i]-1. So j runs p[i]-1 times. In Fortran, the loop is j=1 to p(i)-1, which is correct.

Wait, no. For example, if p(i) is 3, then j runs from 1 to 2 (since p(i)-1=2), so two iterations. Which is correct. Because in Java, j runs from 0 to 1 (inclusive), which is 2 iterations. So yes, Fortran's loop j=1 to p(i)-1 is correct.

But what if p(i) is 1? Then p(i)-1 is 0, the loop j=1 to 0, which doesn't run. Which is correct, because you can't add any more problems.

Thus, the code should handle that.

So the code should handle D=1 to 10.
